answers.author: Robert Carty
answers.text:
A professor in my grad program related an example of this from a past work life. He said he tried this with his executive team. Meetings were much shorter and more productive. People didn't linger or ramble as much, and his impression was that people were more creative and quicker thinkers (the old saying that you think better on your feet). 
For brainstorming sessions, a former colleague recommended a walking meeting. Take a stroll through the park as you have your discussion (obviously this would only work with 2-3 people). Fresh air, scenery and getting your blood moving really helps stimulate the neurons.

answers.author: Gary Edwards
answers.text:
We do not have stand-up meetings, however, this is not a new concept.  Many of the "rock and roll" DJ's working at major market stations in the 50's through the '90's effectively used this approach.  Management took the position that announcers who stood during their airshifts were more alert, spontaneous and creative.  However, these poor guys had to stand for a two, three or four hour shift.  Because a meeting is a relatively short period of time, I think it is an approach worth considering.
